0.name: Data Structure
0.description: A specialized format in the management, organization and storage of data for efficient access to them.

1.name: Discrete Structure
1.description: The study of discrete mathematical structures in computer science.

2.name: Algorithms
2.description: A finite sequence of rigorous instruction used to solve a class of specific problems or to perform a computation.

3.name: Computer Systems
3.description: A complex interconnection of the computer's operating system/hardware and software which work together to provide computing capabilities.

4.name: Performance
4.description: The efficiency and speed of a computer system or application in terms of executing tasks and managing resources—encompassing speed, throughput, latency, and resource utilization.

5.name: Design Patterns
5.description: General, formalized, and reusable descriptions or templates of solutions that can be used to solve common problems when designing an application or system.

6.name: Efficiency
6.description: A property of an algorithm which relates to the amount of the computational resources it uses.

7.name: Higher-Order Programming
7.description: A style that heavily utilizes software components as higher-order functions*, borrowing concepts from models of computations such as lambda calculus; *a function that takes one or more functions as arguments, or returns a function as its result.

8.name: Cleanliness
8.description: The quality of readability and maintainability of the source code in a software project.

9.name: Optimization
9.description: The process of modifying a software system so that the work uses fewer resources, executes more rapidly, operates with less memory storage, or draws less power.

10.name: Frameworks & Integrations
10.description: An abstraction providing a standard of particular functionality to facilitate the development of software applications, products, and solutions.

11.name: Dynamic Programming
11.description: A mathematical and algorithmic optimization method where complicated problems are broken down into simpler sub-problems in a recursive manner.

12.name: Asynchronous Programming
12.description: A technique that enables a program to start a new task while allowing the program to still be responsive to other events, and not having the program to wait for the old task to finish.

13.name: Maintainability
13.description: Advanced concept of efficient code development that improves readability, coupling, or consistency of the code.

14.name: Profiling
14.description: A form of dynamic program analysis that measures the space or time complexity of a program, the usage of particular instructions, or the frequency and duration of function calls.

15.name: Debugging
15.description: The process of finding and resolving bugs—defects or problems that prevent correct operations—within computer programs, software, or systems.

16.name: Responsiveness
16.description: The adaptability of the design in different environments, especially in a web development.

17.name: Software Architecture
17.description: The set of structures needed to reason about a software system and the discipline of creating such structures and systems.

18.name: Automation
18.description: A technique of programming a script or a batch processing that allows repetitive tasks to save time, reduce effort, and perform complex and tedious operations.

19.name: Modular Programming
19.description: A software design technique emphasizing on separating the functionality of a program into independent, interchangable modules such that each contains everything necessary to execute only one aspect of the desired functionality.

20.name: Version Control
20.description: The practice of tracking and managing changes to computer programs and software code.

21.name: Monitoring
21.description: The process of observing and collecting data from software applications, systems, or networks to ensure their proper functioning, performance, and security.

22.name: Scalability
22.description: A software development practice towards a system's ability to increase in performance and decrease in cost with its changes in its application and system processing demands.

23.name: Networking
23.description: A software development technique of writing programs or processes that can communicate with other programs or processes across a network.

24.name: Cloud Computing
24.description: An on-demand access, via the internet, to computing resources—applications, physical and virtual servers, data storage, development tools, networking capabilities, and more—hosted at a remote data center managed by a cloud services provider.

25.name: Systems Design
25.description: The process of defining and developing the architecture, components, modules, interfaces, and data for a system to satisfy the specified requirements of the user.

26.name: Scripting
26.description: A way of delivering instructions that automates various step-by-step functions or processes to a computer as with all forms of programming.

27.name: Software Testing
27.description: The act of examining the artifacts and the behavior of the software under test by validation and verification.

28.name: Software Analysis
28.description: A requirement analysis that aims to gain insights of behavior, performance, and structure by techniques such as code, data, and algorithms examinations.

29.name: Data Handling
29.description: Techniques of recording, collecting, and representing data that is presented into valuable insights or actionable information.

30.name: Software Security
30.description: The concept of implementing security mechanisms to protect software applications and digital solutions from attackers.

31.name: Software Engineering
31.description: An engineering-based approach to design, develop, test, maintain, and evaluate computer software.

32.name: Distributed Computing
32.description: A method of developing a system whose components are located on different networked computers, which communicate and coordinate their actions by passing messages to one another.

33.name: Usability
33.description: A programming technique that allows a software or code to be used by specified consumers with effectiveness, efficiency, and satisfaction in a quantified context of its use.

34.name: CI/CD
34.description: The combined practice of continuous integration (frequent merging of several small changes into a main branch) and continuous delivery (the rapid and reliable software release).

35.name: Big Data
35.description: Organization, administration, and governance of large volumes of both structured and unstructured data.

36.name: Ethical Hacking
36.description: Ethical act of identifying any vulnerabilities or security issues the current system has with the aim to improve upon its security.

37.name: Computer Graphics
37.description: A sub-field of computer science which studies methods for digitally synthesizing and manipulating visual content.

38.name: Cryptography
38.description: the practice and study of techniques for a secure communication in the presence of an adversarial behavior.

39.name: Research
39.description: The systematic investigation into and study of materials, sources, etc, in order to establish facts and reach new conclusions.

40.name: Artificial Intelligence
40.description: A field of study in computer science that develops and studies intelligent machines.

41.name: Game Design
41.description: The software development of video games by the creation of the mechanics, systems, and its rules.

42.name: Computer Vision
42.description: The methods for acquiring, processing, analyzing, and understanding digital images along with the extraction of high-dimensional data from the real world in order to produce numerical or symbolic information.

43.name: Data Science
43.description: An interdisciplinary academic field that uses statistics, scientific computing and methods, processes, algorithms and systems to extract or extrapolate knowledge and insights from potentially noisy, structured, or unstructured data.

44.name: Deep Learning
44.description: The subset of machine learning methods based on artificial neural networks with representation learning.

45.name: Simulation
45.description: The process of modeling a real phenomenon with a set of mathematical formulas.

46.name: VR/AR
46.description: The use of computer modeling and simulation that enables a person to interact with an artificial three-dimensional visual or other sensory environment.

47.name: Advanced Topics
47.description: Subjects, themes, or areas of study that are characterized by a higher level of complexity, depth, and specialization.

48.name: HTML
48.description: The standard markup language for documents designed to be displayed in a web browser; it defines the content and structure of web content.

49.name: php
49.description: A popular general-purpose scripting language that is especially suited to web development.

50.name: Javascript
50.description: A high-level programming language often just-in-time compiled language that conforms to the ECMAScript standard.

51.name: Python
51.description: A high-level, general-purpose, dynamically typed, and garbage-collected programming language that supports multiple programming paradigms, including structured object-oriented and functional programming.

52.name: Laravel
52.description: A free and open-source PHP web framework intended for the development of web applications following the model-view-controller (MVC) architectural pattern, based on Symfony.

53.name: CSS
53.description: A style sheet language used for specifying the presentation and styling of a document written in a markup language such as HTML or XML.

54.name: JQuery
54.description: A JavaScript library designed to simplify HTML DOM tree traversal and manipulation, as well as event handling, CSS animations, and Ajax.

55.name: Ruby
55.description: A dynamic, open source programming language with a focus on simplicity and productivity. It has an elegant syntax that is natural to read and easy to write.

56.name: Flask
56.description: A micro web framework written in Python that does not require particular tools or libraries.

57.name: Sass/SCSS
57.description: A preprocessor scripting language that is interpreted or compiled into Cascading Style Sheets (CSS); SCSS is a newer syntax of the Sass preprocessor scripting language.

58.name: Node.js
58.description: A cross-platform, open-source JavaScript runtime environment that can run on Windows, Linux, Unix, macOS, and more.

59.name: Java
59.description: A high-level, class-based, object-oriented programming language that is designed to have as few implementation dependencies as possible.

60.name: MySQL
60.description: An open-source relational database management system (RDBMS).

61.name: React
61.description: A free and open-source front-end JavaScript library for building user interfaces based on components.

62.name: Vue.js
62.description: An open-source model-view-viewmodel front end JavaScript library for building user interfaces and single-page applications.

63.name: Angular 2+
63.description: A TypeScript-based, free and open-source single-page web application framework.

64.name: Spring (Boot)
64.description: An application framework and inversion of control container for the Java platform; Spring Boot Extension is Spring's convention-over-configuration solution intended to aid in creating production-grade Spring applications with minimal amounts of configuration.

65.name: Git
65.description: A distributed version control system that tracks changes in any set of computer files, usually used for coordinating work among programmers who are collaboratively developing source code during software development.

66.name: Firebase
66.description: A set of backend cloud computing services and application development platforms provided by Google.

67.name: Next.JS
67.description: An open-source web development framework created by the private company Vercel providing React-based web applications with server-side rendering and static website generation.

68.name: Typescript
68.description: A free and open-source high-level programming language developed by Microsoft that adds static typing with optional type annotations to JavaScript.

69.name: PostgreSQL
69.description: A free and open-source relational database management system (RDBMS) emphasizing extensibility and SQL compliance that feature transactions with atomicity, consistency, isolation, durability (ACID) properties, automatically updatable views, materialized views, triggers, foreign keys, and stored procedures.

70.name: Django
70.description: A high-level Python web framework that encourages rapid development and clean, pragmatic design.

71.name: Go
71.description: A statically typed, compiled high-level programming language that has memory safety, garbage collection, structural typing, and CSP-style concurrency.

72.name: Gitlab
72.description: An open source end-to-end software development platform with built-in version control, issue tracking, code review, CI/CD, and more.

73.name: Github
73.description: A developer platform that allows developers to create, store, manage and share their code; it uses Git software, providing the distributed version control of Git plus access control, bug tracking, software feature requests, task management, continuous integration, and wikis for every project.

74.name: Jest
74.description: A JavaScript testing framework designed to ensure correctness of any JavaScript codebase that allows you to write tests with an approachable, familiar and feature-rich API, giving results quickly.

75.name: GraphQL
75.description: an open-source data query and manipulation language for APIs and a query runtime engine that enables declarative data fetching where a client can specify exactly what data it needs from an API.

76.name: MongoDB
76.description: A source-available, cross-platform, document-oriented database program, classified as a NoSQL database product that utilizes JSON-like documents with optional schemas.

77.name: Docker
77.description: A set of platform as a service (PaaS) products that use OS-level virtualization to deliver software in packages called containers.

78.name: Google Cloud Platform
78.description: A suite of cloud computing services, offered by Google, that provides a series of modular cloud services including computing, data storage, data analytics, and machine learning, alongside a set of management tools.

79.name: AWS
79.description: A suite of cloud computing services, offered by Amazon, that provides on-demand cloud computing platforms and APIs to individuals, companies, and governments, on a metered, pay-as-you-go basis.

80.name: C
80.description: a procedural, general-purpose, highly flexible, and powerful computer programming language used to develop operating systems, databases, applications, etc; considered as the mother language of all modern programming languages.

81.name: Ansible
81.description: An open source, command-line IT automation software application written in Python. It can configure systems, deploy software, and orchestrate advanced workflows to support application deployment, system updates, and more.

82.name: Jenkins
82.description: A self-contained, open source automation server which can be used to automate all sorts of tasks related to building, testing, and delivering or deploying software.

83.name: Datadog
83.description: An observability service for cloud-scale applications, providing monitoring of servers, databases, tools, and services, through a SaaS-based data analytics platform; the mascot is a dog named Bits.

84.name: C#
84.description: A general-purpose high-level programming language that can be used to create a number of different programs and applications: mobile apps, desktop apps, cloud-based services, websites, enterprise software and games.

85.name: C++
85.description: A high-level, general-purpose programming language that has object-oriented, generic, and functional features, in addition to facilities for low-level memory manipulation.

86.name: PyTorch
86.description: A machine learning framework based on the Torch library, used for applications such as computer vision and natural language processing.

87.name: Kubernetes
87.description: An open-source container orchestration system for automating software deployment, scaling, and management.

88.name: ASP.NET Core
88.description: An open-source modular web-application framework: a redesign of ASP.NET that unites the previously separate ASP.NET MVC and ASP.NET Web API into a single programming model.

89.name: Unity
89.description: A cross-platform game engine used to create three-dimensional (3D) and two-dimensional (2D) games, as well as interactive simulations and other experiences.

90.name: TensorFlow
90.description: A free and open-source software library for machine learning and artificial intelligence.

91.name: Rust
91.description: A multi-paradigm, general-purpose programming language that emphasizes performance, type safety, and concurrency.

92.name: Symfony
92.description: A free and open-source PHP web application framework and a set of reusable PHP component libraries.

93.name: TailwindCSS
93.description: An open source CSS framework containing a list of utility CSS classes that can be used to style each element by mixing and matching.

94.name: OCaml
94.description: A general-purpose, high-level, multi-paradigm programming language which extends the Caml dialect of ML with object-oriented features.

95.name: Shapes
95.description: Understanding the concept of artwork created through lines or by other shapes such as triangles, circles, and squares; the building blocks of visual arts.

96.name: Notation
96.description: Understanding the system of graphics or symbols, characters and abbreviated expressions used to represent words, sounds, pitches, rhythms, or other elements in a standardized and communicable form.

97.name: Perspective
97.description: The technique to create an impression of space, depth and scale in an artwork.

98.name: Structure
98.description: The technique of arranging the underlying framework that gives form and coherence to the artwork.

99.name: Color
99.description: The technique of adding an element such as hues and tints to convey emotion and mood within an artwork, or in the musical concept: the richness, texture, and tonal qualities that contribute to the overall auditory experience.

100.name: Tone
100.description: The technique of applying a board concept of duration, pitch, intensity, and timbre; in visual art tone refers to the to the value or character of color.

101.name: Tempo
101.description: The technique of utilizing the different speed or pace of a given composition.

102.name: Proportion
102.description: The technique of giving dimensions to a composition; it is related to the relationships between height, width and depth of an artwork.

103.name: Texture
103.description: The technique of applying the perceived surface quality to a work of art; in musical terms, it is how different layers of a piece of music are combined to produce the overall sound.

104.name: Harmony
104.description: The technique of using of colours, shapes, and other elements to create a pleasing or balanced effect.

105.name: Dynamics
105.description: The technique to keep the artwork captivating and thrilling while avoiding predictability by adding movement and energy; in music, it is the variation in loudness between notes or phrases.

106.name: Rhythm
106.description: The technique of implementing the timing of musical sounds and silences that occur over time, or the steps of a dance, or the meter of spoken language and poetry.

107.name: Observation
107.description: Concept of learning by looking at a subject and then making a representation of that subject through an art medium.

108.name: Expression
108.description: Concept of bringing an idea, feeling, and emotion to life through the use of basic art techniques.

109.name: Composition
109.description: Concept of combining and arranging different elements of an artwork to convey specific stories or meaning within an image.

110.name: Intention
110.description: The concept of adding a purpose or motivation to an artwork for it to be considered meaningful, thought-provoking, or impactful.

111.name: Articulation
111.description: The concept of structuring an artwork's clarity, precision, and effectiveness by determining the length of its sound and the shape of its attack and decay.

112.name: Motion
112.description: The study of movement and action in an artwork and the effects of those qualities.

113.name: Material
113.description: The study of a substance or mixture that constitutes an object.

114.name: Anatomy
114.description: The study of the structure of organisms and their parts.

115.name: Narrative
115.description: Any account of a series of related events or experiences presented through a sequence of written or spoken words, movements, or music.

116.name: Voice
116.description: The art of performing a character or providing information to an audience with one's voice.

117.name: Phrasing
117.description: The way of the performer to shapes a sequence of notes or words in a passage to allow expression.

118.name: Sight-Reading
118.description: The practice of reading and performing of a piece in a music notation that the performer has not seen or learned before.

119.name: Shading
119.description: The darkening or colouring of a drawing with lines or blocks of colour, and is often used to create the illusion of depth or make an object three-dimensional.

120.name: Lighting
120.description: The manipulation of light to illuminate a subject or scene, aimed at enhancing the aesthetic qualities, mood, and storytelling aspects of the artwork.

121.name: Genre
121.description: A category of literature, music, or other forms of art or entertainment, based on some set of stylistic criteria.

122.name: Gesture
122.description: The intentional movement, physical or expression, understanding and appreciation of the meaning, emotion, or narrative.

123.name: Modelling
123.description: The process of creating three-dimensional representations of objects, figures, or scenes using various materials and techniques.

124.name: Photography
124.description: The practice of creating images by recording light, either electronically by means of an image sensor, or chemically by means of a light-sensitive material such as photographic film.

125.name: Storyboarding
125.description: The act of organizing illustrations or images that are displayed in sequence for the purpose of pre-visualizing a motion picture, animation, motion graphic or interactive media sequence.

126.name: Dialogue
126.description: The method through which characters— in writing and acting—communicate, express their emotions, and reveal their personalities.

127.name: Performance
127.description: A range of disciplines which are performed in front of a live audience, including theatre, music, and dance.

128.name: Sculpting
128.description: The branch of the three-dimensional art work which is physically presented in the dimensions of height, width and depth.

129.name: Editing
129.description: The process of selecting and preparing written, visual, audible, or cinematic material used by a person or an entity to convey a message or information.

130.name: Animation
130.description: A filmmaking technique by which still images are manipulated to create moving images. In traditional animation, images are drawn or painted by hand on transparent celluloid sheets (cels) to be photographed and exhibited on film.

131.name: Characterization
131.description: The representation of characters (persons, creatures, or other beings) in narrative and dramatic works.

132.name: Technique
132.description: The ability of artists to exert optimal control of their tools or instruments in order to produce the precise artistic effects they desire.

133.name: Rendering
133.description: The process of generating a photorealistic or non-photorealistic image from a 2D or 3D model by means of a computer program.

134.name: Visual Effects
134.description: The process by which imagery is created or manipulated in filmmaking and video production.

135.name: Stagecraft
135.description: A technical aspect of theatrical, film, and video production that includes constructing and rigging scenery; hanging and focusing of lighting; design and procurement of costumes; make-up; stage management; audio engineering; and procurement of props.

136.name: Musicality
136.description: The sensitivity to, knowledge of, or talent for music

137.name: Concept Art
137.description: A form of visual art used to convey an idea for use in films, video games, animation, comic books, television shows, or other media before it is put into the final product.

138.name: Industrial Design
138.description: A process of design applied to physical products that are to be manufactured by mass production.

139.name: Cinematography
139.description: The art of motion picture photography.

140.name: Choreography
140.description: The art or practice of designing sequences of movements of physical bodies (or their depictions) in which motion or form or both are specified.

141.name: Acting
141.description: An activity in which a story is told by means of its enactment by an actor who adopts a character—in theatre, television, film, radio, or any other medium that makes use of the mimetic mode.

142.name: Scriptwriting
142.description: The art and craft of writing scripts for mass media such as feature films, television productions or video games.

143.name: Orchestration
143.description: The study or practice of writing music for an orchestra (or, more loosely, for any musical ensemble, such as a concert band) or of adapting music composed for another medium for an orchestra.

144.name: Virtuoso
144.description: An individual who possesses outstanding talent and technical ability in a particular art or field such as fine arts, music, singing, playing a musical instrument, or composition.

145.name: Linework
145.description: The use of lines—drawn, painted, etched, crafted, or digitally created—to delineate forms, shapes, and contours within a visual composition.

146.name: Typography
146.description: The art and technique of arranging type to make written language legible, readable and appealing when displayed.

147.name: Graphic Design
147.description: An interdisciplinary branch of design and of the fine arts that involves creativity, innovation and lateral thinking using manual or digital tools, where it is usual to use text and graphics to communicate visually.

148.name: Ear-training
148.description: a music theory study in which musicians learn aural skills to identify pitches, intervals, melody, chords, rhythms, solfeges, and other basic elements of music, solely by hearing.

149.name: Repertoire
149.description: A list or set of dramas, operas, musical compositions or roles which a person has learnt or is prepared to perform.

150.name: Conducting
150.description: The art of directing a musical performance, such as an orchestral or choral concert.

151.name: Pencil
151.description: A writing or drawing implement with a solid pigment core in a protective casing that reduces the risk of core breakage, and keeps it from marking the user's hand.

152.name: Pen
152.description: A common drawing and writing instrument that applies ink to a surface.

153.name: Sing
153.description: The act of creating musical sounds with the voice.

154.name: Brush
154.description: A common tool with bristles, wire or other filaments used to apply paint or ink.

155.name: Audacity
155.description: A free and open-source digital audio editor and recording application software for beginners.

158.name: Adobe Photoshop
158.description: A raster graphics editor for professional digital art, especially in raster graphics editing.

159.name: Adobe Audition
159.description: A digital audio workstation developed by Adobe Inc. featuring both a multitrack, non-destructive mix/edit environment and a destructive-approach waveform editing view.

160.name: GarageBand
160.description: A digital audio workstation (DAW) and music sequencer that can record and play back multiple tracks of audio.

165.name: FL Studio
165.description: A digital audio workstation that can be used as either a Virtual Studio Technology (VST) or Audio Unit (AU) instrument in other audio workstation programs, and as a ReWire client.

166.name: MuseScore
166.description: A music notation program for Windows, macOS, and Linux supporting a wide variety of file formats and input methods.

172.name: Brasses Specialization
172.description: A musical instrument that produces sound by sympathetic vibration of air in a tubular resonator in sympathy with the vibration of the player's lips; brass, trombone, trumpet, tuba, or french horn.

173.name: Ableton Live
173.description: A digital audio workstation designed to be an instrument for live performances as well as a tool for composing, recording, arranging, mixing, and mastering.

181.name: Keyboards Specialization
181.description: A musical instrument played using a keyboard, a row of levers that are pressed by the fingers: keyboards, piano, harpsichord, or pipe organ.

186.name: Woodwinds Specialization
186.description: A musical instrument that contains resonator in which a column of air is set into vibration by the player blowing into (or over) a mouthpiece set at or near the end of the resonator; flute, clarinet, oboe, or bassoon.

190.name: Strings Specialization
190.description: A musical instrument that produce sound from vibrating strings when a performer plays or sounds the strings in some manner: guitar, viola, double bass, cello, harp, violin.

194.name: Sibelius
194.description: A scorewriter program used to write, edit, refine, hear, scan, and print music scores.

195.name: Dorico Pro
195.description: A scorewriter software that has advanced scoring capabilities, flexible input methods, and comprehensive notation options.

196.name: Percussions Specialization
196.description: A musical instrument that is sounded by being struck or scraped by a beater including attached or enclosed beaters or rattles struck, scraped or rubbed by hand or struck against another similar instrument: timpani, snare drum, marimba, xylophone, orchestral bass drum, or cymbals.

197.name: Finale
197.description: A scorewriter tool that offers a high level of control for its versatility and robust feature set.
